00040 #ifndef _ray_h
00041 #define _ray_h
00042 
00043 #include "crossplatformexport.h"
00044 #include "vector3.h"
00045 
00046 namespace Ogre
00047 {
00048     class Ray;
00049 }
00050 
00051 
00052 namespace phys
00053 {
00054     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00055     /// @class Ray
00056     /// @headerfile ray.h
00057     /// @brief This is used to indicate a line with one end.
00058     /// @details Currently this is just a collection of two vector3s with a couple
00059     /// of constructors.
00060     class PHYS_LIB Ray
00061     {
00062         public:
00063             /// @brief The origin point of the Vector
00064             Vector3 From;
00065 
00066             /// @brief A point on the line of the ray.
00067             Vector3 To;
00068 
00069             ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00070             // Constructors
00071 
00072             /// @brief Default constructor
00073             /// @details This create a ray starting at 0,0,0 pointing to 0,1,0,
00074             Ray();
00075 
00076             /// @brief Thorough constructor
00077             /// @details This accepts 2 Vector3s and uses them to build the ray
00078             /// @param From_ The origin fo the new Ray
00079             /// @param To_ A point along the line for the destination line.
00080             Ray(Vector3 From_, Vector3 To_);
00081 
00082             /// @brief Compatibily constructor
00083             /// @details This accepts an Ogre Ray, (graphics subsystem) to make ray
00084             /// @param Ray2 This is the Ogre::Ray
00085             Ray(Ogre::Ray Ray2);
00086 
00087             ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00088             // Manual Conversions and adjsutments
00089 
00090             /// @brief Gets an Ogre::Ray that contains this Rays information
00091             /// @details Used to aid interopability, this will return afresh Ogre::Ray with the same data as this Ray
00092             /// @return This returns an Ogre::Ray that contains the same information as this rays information
00093             Ogre::Ray GetOgreRay() const;
00094 
00095             /// @brief Measures the distance distance of this ray
00096             /// @details This uses the distance method of Vector3 to determine the current length of this ray.
00097             /// @return This returns a real value which contains the length
00098             Real Length() const;
00099 
00100             /// @brief This returns the normal for this ray
00101             /// @details This will get a ray that is 1 unit in length with the same From point as this ray, pointing in the same direction as this ray.
00102             /// @return At a ray that is the normal for this array
00103             Ray GetNormal() const;
00104 
00105             /// @brief Turns this Ray into its own normal
00106             /// @details This will change the ray to be exactly 1 unit long, but pointing the same direction.
00107             // /// @return The is the length of the Ray after Normalizing. This could be useful for finding problems with 0 length rays.
00108             void Normalize();
00109 
00110             ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00111             // Real Operators and assignments
00112 
00113             /// @brief This returns a ray lengthened by the given multiple.
00114             /// @details This returns a ray changed in length by the amount in the scalar. Specifically this subracts the From value
00115             /// out of the To value, then multiplies the To value by the scalar, then adds the from value back in.
00116             /// @return This returns a copy of the ray scaled by the requested amount.
00117             /// @param scalar The amount to multiply by.
00118             Ray operator* (const Real &scalar) const;
00119 
00120             /// @brief This returns a ray scaled by the given divisor.
00121             /// @details This returns an ray divided in length by the amount in the scalar. Specifically this subracts the From value
00122             /// out of the To value, then divides the To value by the scalar, then adds the from value back in.
00123             /// @return This returns a copy of the ray scaled by the requested amount.
00124             /// @param scalar The amount to divide by.
00125             Ray operator/ (const Real &scalar) const;
00126 
00127             /// @brief This lengthens the Ray by the given multiple.
00128             /// @details This ray  ischanged in length by the amount in the scalar. Specifically this subracts the From value
00129             /// out of the To value, then multiplies the To value by the scalar, then adds the from value back in.
00130             /// @param scalar The amount to multiply by.
00131             void operator*= (const Real &scalar);
00132 
00133             /// @brief This scales the Ray by the given divisor.
00134             /// @details This ray is divided in length by the amount in the scalar. Specifically this subracts the From value
00135             /// out of the To value, then divides the To value by the scalar, then adds the from value back in.
00136             /// @param scalar The amount to divide by.
00137             void operator/= (const Real &scalar);
00138 
00139     }; // /Ray
00140 
00141 }// /phys
00142 
00143 /// @brief Streaming output operator
00144 /// @details This converts the data of the Ray into a stream Ideal for sending to a log or cout
00145 /// @param stream This is the stream we send our data to.
00146 /// @return This returns an std::ostream which now contains our data.
00147 std::ostream& PHYS_LIB operator << (std::ostream& stream, const phys::Ray& x);
00148 
00149 
00150 #endif
